title: Exporting plots
text: Exporting plots from R can be done in several ways, depending on the desired output format and quality. Here are some common methods to export plots: 1. Using R‚Äôs built-in functions: - png(), jpeg(), tiff(), bmp(): These functions allow you to save plots in various raster formats. You can specify the filename, width, height, and resolution. R      png("plot.png", width=800, height=600)      plot(x, y)      dev.off() - pdf(): This function saves plots in PDF format, which is vector-based and suitable for high-quality prints. R      pdf("plot.pdf", width=8, height=6)      plot(x, y)      dev.off() - svg(): This function saves plots in SVG format, which is also vector-based and ideal for web use. R      svg("plot.svg", width=8, height=6)      plot(x, y)      dev.off()

title: Best Practices
text:
Introduction to Data Visualization

‚ÄúThe simple graph has brought more information to the data analyst‚Äôs mind than any other device.‚Äù - John Tukey



Data visualization transforms complex data into visual insights
Good visualizations tell a story
Poor visualizations mislead or confuse
Every choice matters - especially in healthcare

title: Best Practices
text:
The Big Idea
Can you summarize your message in one sentence?


Your ‚ÄúBig Idea‚Äù should be:

Articulate your point of view: What do you want your audience to know?
Convey what‚Äôs at stake: Why does this matter?
Be a complete sentence: Not just a topic, but a statement

Example: ‚ÄúWe should implement early discharge planning because it reduces re-admissions by 35%‚Äù

title: Best Practices
section: Principle 1: Choose the Right Chart Type
text:
Principle 1: Choose the Right Chart Type
Match your visualization to your data and message
Different types of data require different visualizations:


Simple text: When you have 1-2 numbers
Tables: For multiple units, precise values
Heatmaps: For tables with many values
Scatter plots: For relationships between variables
Line charts: For continuous data over time
Slopegraphs: For comparing two time points
Bar charts: For categorical comparisons

title: Best Practices
text:
Chart Type: Simple Text

Effective: When you have just 1-2 key numbers, text is more impactful than a chart. Makes the metric impossible to miss.

title: Best Practices
text:
Chart Type: Table

Effective: Tables are ideal when you need to show precise values with different units of measure. Better than a chart when exact numbers matter.

title: Best Practices
text:
Chart Type: Heatmap

Effective: Heatmaps encode values with color, making it easy to spot patterns in large tables. Great for identifying hot/cold spots quickly.

title: Best Practices
text:
Chart Type: Scatter Plot

Effective: Scatter plots reveal relationships between two continuous variables. The trend line makes the correlation clear.

title: Best Practices
text:
Chart Type: Line Chart

Effective: Line charts show trends over time. The continuous line emphasizes the progression and makes patterns clear.

title: Best Practices
text:
Chart Type: Slopegraph

Effective: Slopegraphs are perfect for comparing two time points. They show both ranking and magnitude of change clearly.

title: Best Practices
text:
Chart Type: Horizontal Bar Chart

Effective: Horizontal bars are easier to read than vertical, especially with long labels. Natural left-to-right reading.

title: Best Practices
text:
Avoid: Line Charts for Categories

Ineffective: Lines suggest continuous change between points, but there‚Äôs no meaningful order or connection between these categories.

title: Best Practices
text:
Chart Type: Stacked Bar Chart

Effective: Stacked bars show part-to-whole relationships over time. Easy to see both total volume and composition.

title: Best Practices
section: Avoid: Y-Axis Not Starting at Zero
text:
Avoid: Y-Axis Not Starting at Zero

Ineffective: Truncating the Y-axis exaggerates small differences. Makes 3% variation look like massive differences in performance.

title: Best Practices
text:
Better: Y-Axis Starting at Zero

Effective: Starting at zero shows true proportions. All hospitals are performing well - the differences are minor.

title: Best Practices
text:
Avoid: Pie Charts

Ineffective: Humans struggle to compare angles and areas. Which is bigger - Respiratory or Other? Hard to tell precisely.

title: Best Practices
text:
Better: Horizontal Bar Chart

Effective: Horizontal bars make comparisons effortless. Rankings and differences are immediately clear.

title: Best Practices
text:
Principle 2: Eliminate Clutter
Remove anything that doesn‚Äôt add value


Remove chart borders and backgrounds
Lighten or remove gridlines

Remove redundant data labels
Direct labeling > legends
Clean up axis labels
Every element should earn its place

title: Best Practices
text:
Example: Default Plot (Cluttered)

Ineffective: Gray background, gridlines, legend, and borders all compete for attention. The data gets lost in visual clutter.

title: Best Practices
text:
Example: Decluttered with Direct Labels

Effective: Clean background, minimal gridlines, direct labels. Every element serves the data. The message is clear.

title: Best Practices
text:
Principle 3: Use Preattentive Attributes
Guide attention with attributes processed in <250ms


Color: Most powerful
Size: Indicates importance
Position: Spatial relationships
Intensity: Bold vs light
Use strategically - don‚Äôt dilute attention

title: Best Practices
text:
Example: All Equal (No Focus)

Ineffective: All bars are equal - where should the viewer look? No visual hierarchy means no clear message.

title: Best Practices
text:
Example: Strategic Highlighting

Effective: Red instantly draws the eye to the problem. Gray provides context without competing for attention.

title: Best Practices
text:
Principle 4: Gray and Bold Technique
Use color to highlight, gray to push back


Bold color for what matters most
Gray for context
Maximum one bold color per chart
Creates instant visual hierarchy

title: Best Practices
text:
Example: Too Many Colors (Confusing)

Ineffective: Too many colors compete for attention. Is this chart trying to highlight everything? That means nothing stands out.

title: Best Practices
text:
Example: Gray and Bold (Clear Message)

Effective: Red highlights the problem specialties. Gray provides context. One glance tells the whole story.

title: Best Practices
text:
Principle 5: Think Like a Designer
Alignment, white space, and contrast


Alignment: Left-align text
White space: Give room to breathe
Contrast: Create visual hierarchy
Consistency: Same fonts, colors

title: Best Practices
text:
Example: Poor Design Choices

Ineffective: Centered title, clashing colors, no subtitle, unclear which line is which. Multiple design problems distract from the data.

title: Best Practices
text:
Example: Good Design Principles

Effective: Left-aligned title, clear subtitle, harmonious colors, clean design. Professional and easy to understand.

title: Best Practices
text:
Principle 6: Tell a Story
Move from descriptive to narrative


Descriptive: What is this?
Narrative: So what?
State your insight in the title
Use subtitles for context

title: Best Practices
text:
Example: Descriptive Title (What?)

Ineffective: The title just describes what‚Äôs in the chart. No insight, no message, no story. Makes the viewer do all the work.

title: Best Practices
text:
Example: Insight-Driven Title (So What?)

Effective: Title states the insight. Subtitle adds context. Color highlights the key period. The story is told instantly.

title: Best Practices
text:
Before: Default Visualization

Ineffective: Default theme, no focus, legend requires back-and-forth eye movement. No clear message about what matters.

title: Best Practices
text:
After: Storytelling Approach

Effective: Clean design, strategic color, insight-driven title, direct labeling. All six principles working together.

title: Best Practices
text:
Key Takeaways


Choose the right chart - Match to data type
Eliminate clutter - Remove non-value elements
Use preattentive attributes - Guide attention
Gray and bold - Highlight vs context
Think like a designer - Alignment, space, contrast
Tell a story - State your insight

title: Best Practices
text:
Resources

Book: Storytelling with Data by Cole Nussbaumer Knaflic
Book: The Visual Display of Quantitative Information by Edward Tufte
Website: storytellingwithdata.com
Website: r-graph-gallery.com

title: Best Practices
text:
Thank You!
Every visualization is a story.
Make sure yours is worth telling.

‚ÄúThe greatest value of a picture is when it forces us to notice what we never expected to see.‚Äù - John Tukey

title: Introduction
text:
Introduction
Why Visualize Data?
Grammer of Graphics: the ggplot2 Philosophy
Foundations of Visualization
These concepts form the backbone of any ggplot2 plot. - Data ‚Äì The dataset being visualized - Aesthetics ‚Äì Mapping data to visual properties (aes()) - Geometries ‚Äì Visual marks like points, lines, bars (geom_) - Statistics ‚Äì Summarizing or transforming data (stat_) - Coordinates ‚Äì Defining the plotting space (coord_) - Facets ‚Äì Creating subplots for subsets of data (facet_wrap, facet_grid) - Scales ‚Äì Mapping data values to aesthetics (scale_) - Guides ‚Äì Legends and axes to interpret scales
Styling and Layout These elements refine the appearance and readability of plots. - Themes ‚Äì Overall visual style (theme_*, theme()) - Color ‚Äì Using palettes and contrast effectively - Labels ‚Äì Axis labels, data labels (labs(), geom_text) - Titles ‚Äì Plot titles and subtitles - Captions ‚Äì Additional context below the plot - Margins ‚Äì Adjusting spacing around plot elements - Annotations ‚Äì Highlighting specific data points (annotate(), geom_label)
Structural Composition These concepts help build complex and layered plots. - Layers ‚Äì Combining multiple geoms and stats - Customization ‚Äì Tailoring plots to specific needs - Exporting ‚Äì Saving plots (ggsave(), formats) - Reproducibility ‚Äì Ensuring consistent outputs across sessions
Interpretation and Communication These ideas focus on the purpose and impact of visualization. - Data Preparation ‚Äì Cleaning and transforming data - Data Exploration ‚Äì Using plots to uncover patterns - Communication ‚Äì Conveying insights effectively - Storytelling ‚Äì Building narrative through visuals - Accessibility ‚Äì Designing for diverse audiences
Advanced Techniques and Tools These extend ggplot2‚Äôs capabilities and introduce interactivity. - Interactivity ‚Äì Dynamic plots with plotly, ggiraph - Animation ‚Äì Time-based visuals with gganimate - Tools and Libraries ‚Äì Supporting packages (ggplot2, patchwork, cowplot) - ggplot2 ‚Äì Core package for layered grammar of graphics - Other R Packages ‚Äì lattice, plotly, shiny, etc.
Mapping aesthetics to data variables - Common aesthetics: x, y, color, fill, size, shape, alpha - Aesthetic mappings are defined inside aes() function - Example: aes(x = variable1, y = variable2, color = category) - Aesthetic mappings can be global (in ggplot()) or local (in geom_*) - Global mappings apply to all layers, local mappings override global ones for that layer

title: Debugging Plots
text: Debugging plots are essential tools for diagnosing issues in data visualization and analysis. They help identify problems such as incorrect data representation, scaling issues, or unexpected patterns in the data. In this guide, we will explore various techniques and tools for creating effective debugging plots.

title: Plotting Tools
text:
Plotting Tools
This chapter introduces various tools and libraries available in R for creating visualizations. It covers base R plotting functions, as well as popular packages like ggplot2 and lattice, which offer advanced capabilities for creating complex and customizable plots.

title: Advanced plots
text:
‚ñ∏ Categorical

Faceted bar plots - Spider / radar charts - Tree Map ### ‚ñ∏ Continuous
2D density plot
Hexbin plot

title: Debugging Plots
text: Debugging plots are essential tools for diagnosing issues in data visualization and analysis. They help identify problems such as incorrect data representation, scaling issues, or unexpected patterns in the data. In this guide, we will explore various techniques and tools for creating effective debugging plots.
